intro: Ichnocarpus wallichii, commonly known as the Indian mallow or wild cotton, is a flowering plant native to the Indian subcontinent. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its hairy, lance-shaped leaves and showy, pale pink to purple flowers. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, hairy seeds. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in open forests and along riverbanks. Due to its ornamental value and traditional uses, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and herbal medicine.
